overview: The different types of court - magistrates' court, Crown Court and youth court - the crimes they deal with and the level of sentences they can give
title: Courts - the different types

table.body:
All criminal cases start in a magistrates’ court which has either:

- 3 magistrates
- a district judge

There isn’t a jury in a magistrates' court.

##Cases a magistrates' court deals with

A magistrates' court normally deals with cases known as ‘summary offences’, eg:

- most motoring offences
- minor theft, eg stealing from a shop
- being drunk and disorderly

It can also deal with more serious offences, including:

- burglary
- drugs offences

These are called 'either way' offences and can be dealt with either by a magistrates' court or a Crown Court.

##Sentences a magistrates' court can give

The maximum punishment a magistrates’ court can give for a single summary offence is:

- 6 months in prison (12 months in total for more than 1 offence)
- a fine of up to £5,000

The court can decide, for example, to give you a fine as well as a prison sentence.

^If the magistrates decide your sentence should be for longer than 6 months, they can send your case to the Crown Court for sentencing.^

##When you may be put on bail or remand

At your hearing, the court may either:
 
- let you go home on ‘court bail’ 
- remand you in custody

This may happen if:

- another court hearing is needed
- the court needs more information about you before sentencing you
- your case is sent to the Crown Court for sentencing

The court will base its decision whether to put you on bail or remand you in custody, by considering if you're:

- likely to commit another crime while on bail
- unlikely to go to another court hearing
- at risk of harming yourself or someone else

##Appealing a sentence or conviction

If you disagree with the court's verdict, you may be able to [appeal](/appeal-against-sentence-conviction/magistrates-court-verdict "Appeal against a magistrates' court verdict").
table.title: Magistrates' courts

table.body:
A Crown Court deals with:

- serious criminal cases, eg murder, rape or robbery
- appeals against a magistrates' court conviction or sentence
- cases sent from a magistrates' court for sentencing

A Crown Court:

- normally has a jury - which decides if you're guilty or not
- has a judge - who decides what sentence you get

^Your solicitor (if you have one) can explain what happens in court - the judge and court staff will also give instructions about the trial.^

##Sentences a Crown Court can give

A Crown Court can give a [range of sentences](/how-sentences-are-worked-out "How sentences are worked out") including:

- [community sentences](/community-sentences "Community sentences")
- [prison sentences](/types-of-prison-sentence "Types of prison sentences") - including life sentences

##When you may be put on bail or remand
 
At your hearing, the court may either:

- let you go home on ‘court bail’ 
- remand you in custody

This may happen if:

- another court hearing is needed
- the court needs more information about you before sentencing you

The court will base its decision whether to put you on bail or remand you in custody, by considering if you're:

- likely to commit another crime while on bail
- unlikely to go to another court hearing
- at risk of harming yourself or someone else

##Appealing a sentence or conviction
If you disagree with the court's verdict, you may be able to [appeal](/appeal-against-sentence-conviction/crown-court-verdict "Appeal against a Crown Court verdict").
table.title: Crown Court

table.body:
Youth courts are for people aged under 18.

All criminal cases start in a youth court which has either:

- 3 magistrates
- a district judge

There isn’t a jury in a youth court.

^You must have a parent or guardian with you if you go to a youth court.^

##Types of cases a youth court deals with

A youth court deals with cases like:

- theft and burglary
- anti-social behaviour
- drugs offences

For serious crimes, like murder or rape, the case starts in the youth court but will be sent to a Crown Court.

##Sentences a youth court can give

The court can give a [range of sentences](/how-sentences-are-worked-out "How sentences are worked out") including:

- [community sentences](/community-sentences/community-sentences-if-you-are-under-18 "Community sentences")
- [Detention and Training Orders](/types-of-prison-sentence/sentences-for-young-people "Types of prison sentence") carried out in secure centres for young people

##When you may be put on bail or remand 

At your hearing, the court will either:

- let you go home on ‘court bail’
- remand you in custody

The court will make its decision by considering if you're:

- likely to commit another crime while on bail
- unlikely to go to any other court hearings in the future
- at risk of harming yourself or someone else

##Appealing a sentence

If you disagree with the court's verdict, you may be able to appeal. Court staff can give you information on how to appeal.
table.title: Youth courts
